Yes, horses and ponies can develop strong emotional bonds with humans, which can affect their relationships with other members of their herd. However, the degree to which the bond with humans affects their relationship with other horses or ponies can vary depending on the individual horse or pony and the specific herd dynamics.

When a horse or pony forms a bond with a human, it can become more dependent on the human and may prioritize the relationship with the human over its relationships with other horses or ponies. This can lead to conflicts with other members of the herd or changes in the horse's social behavior, such as becoming more aggressive or submissive.

However, if the relationship with the human is well-managed and balanced with appropriate social interactions with other horses or ponies, it is possible for the horse or pony to maintain healthy relationships with both humans and members of its herd.

Overall, forming close bonds with humans can affect the relationships of horses and ponies with other members of their herd, but with appropriate management and attention to socialization, these competing loyalties can often be managed successfully.
